item.title: Hello World: Why I Started This Blog
item.description:
This is where the compartmentalized chaos begins.

I’ve been meaning to start writing for years. Not the professional kind—the kind of reports and documentation that fills most of our days—but the exploratory kind. The kind where you start with a half-formed thought and see where it leads.

The Intersection of Ideas

What fascinates me most is where different domains collide:

  • AI and Philosophy: What does it mean for machines to “think”? How do large language models challenge our notions of understanding and consciousness?
  • Product Management and Human Behavior: Every product decision is ultimately about understanding people—their needs, fears, and aspirations.
  • Technology and Culture: How do the tools we build shape the societies we live in?

item.title: Understanding Transformers: A First Principles Approach
item.description:
The transformer architecture, introduced in the 2017 paper “Attention Is All You Need,” revolutionized natural language processing. But what makes it so powerful?

The Core Intuition

Imagine you’re reading a sentence:

“The cat sat on the mat because it was tired.”

When you read “it,” your brain automatically connects it to “cat” rather than “mat.” You’re performing attention—focusing on the relevant context to understand meaning.

Transformers do something similar, but mathematically.

item.title: Three Product Thinking Frameworks That Changed How I Build
item.description:
After years of building products, I’ve found that the right mental model at the right time can unlock breakthroughs. Here are three frameworks that fundamentally changed how I approach product development.

1. Jobs-to-be-Done (JTBD)

The insight: People don’t buy products. They hire them to do a job.

When someone buys a drill, they don’t want a drill—they want a hole. When they download a meditation app, they don’t want an app—they want calm.
